title: Brooks Robinson, Hall of Fame Orioles third baseman, dies at 86
description: Hall of Fame third baseman Brooks Robinson, whose deft glovework and folksy manner made him one of the most beloved and accomplished athletes in Baltimore history, has died. He was 86.

title: Russian appeals court upholds opposition leader Alexei Navalny's 19-year prison term
description: Navalny, a fierce critic of Russian President Vladimir Putin, says the charges against him are politically motivated.

title: A judge says Trump is liable for fraud in New York civil lawsuit
description: Judge Arthur Engoron finds that Trump and his associates exaggerated the former president's net worth in order to complete deals and receive more financing.

title: California is first state to levy a tax on guns and ammo to fund safety programs
description: New law will impose an additional 11% in addition to federal tax. It's one of nearly two dozen gun laws signed into law on Tuesday. but Newsom acknowledges some might not survive legal challenges.

title: Barry Manilow just broke Elvis's Las Vegas record
description: Barry Manilow has just overtaken The King himself, Elvis Presley, for the most shows at Westgate Las Vegas Resort & Casino.

title: New California law bars schoolbook bans based on racial and LGBTQ topics
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom called the new measure "long overdue," saying that the banning binge of diverse materials has to come to an end.

title: 'People Collide' is a 'Freaky Friday'-type exploration of the self and persona
description: Isle McElroy's novel covers a deep exploration of marriage, love, and the ways we know one another — while also touching on how so much of how we navigate the world depends on how it sees us.

title: How to watch the second GOP presidential debate
description: Seven Republicans vying for the GOP presidential nomination will take the stage in California Wednesday night for the second GOP debate of the 2024 elections. But the front runner is skipping — again.

title: Irish gymnastics group apologizes after a Black girl was skipped at a medal ceremony
description: Gymnastics Ireland has apologized for the incident. But the girl's mother says the group hasn't done enough. Video shows an official giving medals to a line of girls except the only Black participant.

title: Ford's Theatre tickets from the night Lincoln was assassinated sell for $262,500
description: The two tickets match the marks of what's thought to be the only other used ticket from the night John Wilkes Booth shot Lincoln on April 14, 1865.

title: Hans Niemann pooh-poohs a chess cheating theory that's based on vibrating beads
description: Chess prodigy Hans Niemann is competing in the World Junior Chess Championship — but he's also answering questions about an outlandish cheating theory.

title: Cars are a major predator for wildlife. How is nature adapting to our roads?
description: Environmental journalist Ben Goldfarb says cars are killing animals, while highways cut off them off from their food sources and migration paths. His new book is Crossings.

title: JPMorgan to pay $75 million over claims it enabled Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking
description: The Virgin Islands had argued that JPMorgan had been complicit in Epstein's behavior and did not raise any red flags to law enforcement or bank regulators about Epstein being a "high risk" customer.

title: U.S. sues Amazon in a monopoly case that could be existential for the retail giant
description: The FTC lawsuit against Amazon could be existential for the company. It accuses Amazon of suffocating rivals and raising costs for both sellers and shoppers.

title: Senate Democrats to Bob Menendez: Resign
description: Democrats are abandoning New Jersey Sen. Bob Menendez in the wake of his federal indictment in a corruption scheme involving his wife and local businessmen.

title: Supreme Court rejects Alabama's defiance in voting case
description: In June, the court ruled that Alabama's Republican-drawn congressional map violated the Voting Rights Act.

title: How NPR covered the missionary who ran a center for malnourished kids where 105 died
description: In 2019, NPR covered the story of Renee Bach, who said she was called by God to serve the children of Uganda. Now HBO is presenting her story in the documentary series 'White Savior.'

title: Hunter Biden sues Rudy Giuliani for 'total annihilation' of digital privacy
description: The lawsuit alleges that Rudy Giuliani and an associate's actions are unlawful under California law, and it says Giuliani and the associate have refused to return Hunter Biden's data.

title: Up First briefing: Biden visits UAW; Congress tackles shutdown; Olympic doping hearing
description: Biden will make a historic visit to picketing autoworkers. Congress returns four days before a potential government shutdown. A hearing for Kamila Valieva's Olympic doping scandal begins today.

title: At least 20 dead in gas station blast as Nagorno-Karabakh residents flee to Armenia
description: Separatist authorities in Nagorno-Karabakh said at least 20 people were killed and nearly 300 others injured by an explosion at a gas station as people seeking to flee to Armenia lined up for fuel.

title: Agriculture secretary says government shutdown would impact department's programs
description: NPR's A Martinez talks to Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack about programs — such as the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program — which would be affected if the government shuts down.

title: An overdose drug is finally over-the-counter. Is that enough to stop the death toll?
description: Narcan is now available in drug stores without a prescription. The nasal spray can save a life by stopping an opioid overdose. But will people pay the price and ask for it by name?

title: Millions of Americans will lose food assistance if the government shuts down
description: A shutdown would affect the nearly 7 million women and children who rely on WIC for healthy food. Free school lunch and Meals on Wheels are also at risk, and SNAP could be impacted eventually too.

title: Kamila Valieva doping scandal that rocked the Beijing Olympics may finally be settled
description: The Court of Arbitration for Sport begins a hearing Tuesday into the doping scandal of Russian figure skater Kamila Valieva. U.S. skaters still haven't received team medals from the 2022 Winter Games.

title: How new borrowers can prepare for their first student loan payment
description: When student loan bills begin coming due in October, new borrowers will take their first steps on the long road to paying off their debt. These tools and tips can help ease the journey.

title: In some states, more than half of the local election officials have left since 2020
description: Election conspiracies have fundamentally changed the job of local voting officials, and many don't want to take it anymore.

title: She survived a horrific crash. This is why she now keeps a blanket in her trunk
description: After Laura Carstensen was badly injured in a car crash, two strangers stopped to help her. Their small act of help made a lasting impression.

title: Why many business owners would love it if you stopped using your credit card
description: The fees merchants pay for accepting credit cards are much higher in the U.S. than in Europe. Ice cream shop owner Victor Garcia, for example, paid more than $25,000 in swipe fees last year.

title: Autoworkers will get a historic visitor to the picket line: President Biden
description: Biden will join the United Auto Workers in Michigan on Tuesday, an extraordinary step for a sitting president.

title: Washington prepares for the shutdown that was never supposed to happen
description: Congress is just days away from a possible government shutdown with few solutions being discussed.

title: Ford pauses construction of Michigan battery plant amid contract talks with UAW union
description: The move comes as the company is in the midst of national contract talks with the United Auto Workers union, which wants to represent workers at battery factories and win them top wages.

title: First of thousands of Lahaina residents return to homes destroyed by deadly wildfire
description: In the days after the Aug. 8 wildfire, some people were able to return to their properties to evaluate the damage. But since then, the burned area has been off-limits to all but authorized workers.

title: A blast in Nagorno-Karabakh injures more than 200, while thousands flee to Armenia
description: The explosion at fuel storage facility wounded more than 200 people, the Nagorno-Karabakh human rights ombudsman said. Meanwhile, thousands of Nagorno-Karabakh residents have fled to Armenia.
